II particu]aily direct yoni attention to the Great Light in Masonry, the Holy Bible. Howsoever men differ in ci-ced oi theology, all good men are agreed that within the covers of the Holy Bible are found those principles of morality which lay the founda - tion upon which to build ri righteous life. Freema - somy, therefore, opens this Book upon its altars, 47. with the command to each of its votaries that he diligently study therein to learn the way to ever - lasting life. Adopting no particular creed, forbid - ding sectarian discussion within its Lodge rooms, encouraging each to be steadfast in the faith of his acceptance, Freemasonry takes all good men by tire hand, and, leading them to its altars, points to the open Bible thereon, and urges upon each that he faithfully direct his steps through life by the Light lie there shall find and as lie there shall find it, ~f, fioni our sacred altars, the atheist, the infidel, tIre li-religious man, or the libertine, should evei- be able to wrest this book of Sacred Law, and thins remove, or even obscure, the greatest Light in Masonry, thai Light which for centuries has been the rule and guide of Freeniasoirs, then could we no longer claim for ourselves the gr-eat rank and title of Free anuh Accepted Masons; but, so long as flint Sacred Light shines upon onr altars, so long as it illunilnates the pathway of the Craftsman by its golden i-ays of truth, so long, and no longer, can Freemasonry live and shed its beneficent influence upon mankind Gunid, then, that Book of Sacred and xmmutable Law as you would guard your very life. By the exercise of Brotherly Love, we are taught to regard the human race as one family: the high, the low, the rich, the poor, who—created by one Almighty Parent, and inhabiting the same planet— zhouhd aid, support, aed protect one another. On this principle, Masonry unites men of every coun - try, sect, and opinion, and promotes true friendship among those ivho might otherovise have remained perpetually at a distance. To relieve the distressed is a duty ineumhent on all m~ea, particularhy upon Masons who are linked together by a chain of sincere affection. To soothe the unhappy, to sympathize with them in their mis - fortunes, to compassionate their miseries, and to re - store peace to their troubled minds, are ainis we have ia view. On this basis we establish our connec - tions and form our friendships. Truth is a divine attribute and the foundation of every virtue. To be good and true is the fmrrt les - son we are taught in Masonry. Man that is born of a wonian is of few days, and full of trouble. He cometh forth as a flower, and is cut down; he fleeth also as a shadow, and continueth not.
